summary.para: The instance is not connected, but it was connected, or tried to connect, once.
In this state some properties retain their values from when the instance was connecting/ was connected.
For example the property may have a value in this state, where it definitely won't have one in the state.
Instances of this class can connect to an IMAP server.
Before calling one of the methods set the and properties at a minimum.
See and .
Also consider setting the property.
Note that the class implements , so you should dispose instances when you are finished with them.

Capabilities that you wish the instance to ignore.

The server that the instance should connect to.

Sets the server that the instance should connect to, defaulting the port to 143 and SSL to false.

Can't be called while connected.

summary.para: Indicates if the caller can handle mailbox referrals.
If this is set to false the instance will not return remote mailboxes in mailbox lists.
Being able to handle mailbox referrals means handling the exceptions that may be raised by the library when accessing remote mailboxes.
See RFC 2193, , , , and .
Determines what details about mailboxes are available from the mailbox cache.
Can't be set while connected.
Controls the size of writes to the network.
You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance.
Higher values are presumably more efficient.
Sets parameters that control what the instance does while idle.
Set to null to stop the instance from doing anything.
If set, the instance determines that it is idle after the specified time and then issues periodic IDLE (rfc 2177) or CHECK/ NOOP IMAP commands.
The default control on the size of reads from streams provided to append.
You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can terminate the instance.
The configuration that controls the number of messages fetched at one time.
You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
The configuration that controls the number of bytes fetched from the server at one time.
You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
The configuration that controls the number of bytes written to the output stream at one time when fetching.
You might want to limit this to increase the speed with which you can cancel the fetch.
The encoding to use when UTF8 (rfc 6855) is not supported directly by the server.
The default value is UTF8.
The ID details to send to the server if it supports the ID command (rfc 2971).
This is the ASCII version of the details.
If the server supports UTF8 and is set, those details will be used in preference to these.
The default details are those of the library.
Set to null to send nothing.
The ID details to send to the server if it supports the ID command (rfc 2971).
This is the UTF8 version of the details.
If this is set to null or the server does not support UTF8 then the details will be used instead.
The default is null.
The ID details of the connected (or last connected) server, if it supports the ID command (rfc 2971).
Set during connect.
The namespace details for the connected (or last connected) account.
Set during connect.
If namespaces (rfc 2342) are not supported by the server the library creates one personal namespace using the delimiter retrieved using LIST.
The inbox of the connected (or last connected) account.
Set during connect.
Details of the currently selected mailbox, if any.
The currently selected mailbox, if any.

summary.para: The TLS requirement.
TLS can be established by specifying SSL in the server to be used or by the use of the IMAP STARTTLS command during connect if it is supported by the server.
The library will automatically use IMAP STARTTLS if it is offered and the server does not specify SSL unless the instance has been told to ignore the STARTTLS capability.
See , , and .

member.summary: Gets a summary of the feedback.

summary.para: A summary of a store operation.
Each message counts towards ONE of;
Generally + is the number of definite non-updates.
Generally > 0 indicates that a may be worth trying to get any pending updates (which should convert all the notreflects to expunged or reflects).
> 0 indicates that a blind update was done so there isn't enough information to say if the store happened or not.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.WasNotUnchangedSinceCount
member.summary: An IMAP MODIFIED response was received (=> _NOT_ updated by the command).

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.ExpungedCount
member.summary: The number where the message cache indicates that the message is expunged.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.UnknownCount
member.summary: The number where the internal message handle isn't known (e.g. from a ) or the message cache does not contain the flags.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.ReflectsOperationCount
member.summary: The number where the flags in the message cache reflect the update.

member.name: F:work.bacome.imapclient.sStoreFeedbackSummary.NotReflectsOperationCount
member.summary: The number where the flags in the message cache do not reflect the update.

summary.para: Represents a set of characters that are valid in a parsing context.
Each static member defines a different set of characters.
Intended for internal use.
Provides an API that allows interaction with an IMAP mailbox.
Instances are only valid whilst the containing cIMAPClient remains connected. Reconnecting the client will not bring mailbox instances back to life.
Fired when new messages arrive in the mailbox.
The mailbox name including the full hierarchy.
The hierarchy delimiter used in .
The path of the parent mailbox.
Will be null if there is no parent mailbox.
The name of the mailbox.
As compared to this does not include the hierarchy.
True if this instance represents the inbox.
True if the mailbox exists on the server.
Subscribed mailboxes and levels in the mailbox hierarchy do not need to exist.
False if the mailbox can definitely not contain child mailboxes.
See the IMAP \Noinferiors flag.
True if the mailbox can be selected.
See the IMAP \Noselect flag.
Indicates if the mailbox has been marked "interesting" by the server.
Null indicates that the server didn't say either way.
See the IMAP \Marked and \Unmarked flags.
If true the mailbox is definitely a remote mailbox.
If the connected server supports rfc 5258, if this flag is false the mailbox is definitely not a remote mailbox, otherwise it still may be one.
Remote mailboxes will never be returned by the library if the is set to false.
Indicates if the mailbox had children when the property was refreshed.
Null indicates that the server didn't say either way.
See the IMAP \HasChildren and \HasNoChildren flags.
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \All flag indicating that the mailbox contains all messages.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Archive flag indicating that the mailbox contains the message archive.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Drafts flag indicating that the mailbox contains draft messages.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Flagged flag indicating that the mailbox contains flagged messages.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Junk flag indicating that the mailbox contains junk mail.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Sent flag indicating that the mailbox contains copies of messages that have been sent.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
If true the mailbox was marked with the IMAP \Trash flag indicating that the mailbox contains copies of messages that are deleted.
Null indicates that the specialuse flags are not being cached, see .
Indicates if this mailbox is subscribed to.
The number of messages in the mailbox.
Null indicates that the messagecount is not being cached (see ) or was not sent by the server when requested.
This property always has an up-to-date value when the mailbox is selected.
The number of recent messages in the mailbox.
Null indicates that the recentcount is not being cached (see ) or was not sent by the server when requested.
This property always has an up-to-date value when the mailbox is selected.
The predicted UID that will be given to the next new message entering the mailbox.
Null indicates that the uidnext is not being cached (see ) or was not sent by the server when requested.
When the mailbox is selected, zero indicates that the value is unknown.
When the mailbox is selected this property may not be up-to-date: see the value of for the potential inaccuracy in this property value.
This is the number of messages that arrived since the mailbox was opened for which the library has not seen the value of the UID.
Indicates how inaccurate the is.
The UIDValidity of the mailbox.
Null indicates that the mailbox does not support UIDs or that the UIDValidity is not being cached (see ).
This property always has a value when the mailbox is selected, however zero indicates that the server does not support UIDs. (Also see .)
The number of unseen messages in the mailbox.
Null indicates that the unseencount is not being cached (see ) or was not sent by the server when requested.
When the mailbox is selected this property will always have a value but it may not be up-to-date: see the value of for the potential inaccuracy of this property value.
To initialise the value of this property value when the mailbox is selected use .
To maintain the value of this property when the mailbox is selected use on the new messages that arrive (see ).
This is the number of messages for which the library is unsure of the value of the IMAP \Seen flag.
Indicates how inaccurate the is.
To keep this value at zero see the technique outlined here: .
See RFC 7162.
Null indicates that the highestmodseq is not being cached (see ) or was not sent by the server when requested.
When the mailbox is selected this property will always have a value but zero indicates that RFC 7162 is not supported on the mailbox.
Indicates if the mailbox has been selected once in this session.
Indicates if the mailbox has been selected for update once in this session.
Indicates if the mailbox has been selected readonly once in this session.
Indicates if the mailbox does not have persistent UIDs.
Null if the mailbox has never been selected.
The defined flags in the mailbox.
Null if the mailbox has never been selected.
The flags that the client can change permanently in this mailbox when it is selected for update.
Null if the mailbox has never been selected for update.
The flags that the client can change permanently in this mailbox when it is selected readonly.
Null if the mailbox has never been selected readonly.
Indicates if the mailbox is currently the selected mailbox.
Indicates if the mailbox is currently selected for update.
Indicates if the mailbox is currently selected but the mailbox can't be modified.

Returns the list of message attachments.
If the internal message cache does not contain the bodystructure of the message, it will be fetched from the server.
The library defines an attachment as a message part with a disposition of attachment.
If there are alternate versions of an attachment only one of the alternates is included in the returned list (the first one).
The returned list may be empty.
The size in bytes of the plain text parts of the message.
If the internal message cache does not contain the bodystructure of the message, it will be fetched from the server.
The library defines plain text parts as parts with a MIME type of text/plain and without a disposition of 'attachment'.
If there are alternate versions of a part only one of the alternates is used in calculating the size (the first one).

The normalised (delimiters, quoting, comments and white space removed) message-ids from the references header field, or null if there was no references header field or if the references header field could not be parsed.
If the internal message cache does not contain the references header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server.
The importance value from the importance header field, or null if there was no importance header field or if the importance header field could not be parsed.
If the internal message cache does not contain the importance header field of the message, it will be fetched from the server.
Ensures that the internal message cache contains the specified items for this message instance.
The missing items will be fetched from the server.

param.name: pItems
param.para: The items required in the cache.
Note that the has implicit conversions from other types including (so you can use values of those types as parameters to this method).

returns.para: True if the fetch populated the cache with the requested items, false otherwise.
False indicates that the message is expunged.

summary.para: Fetches the message's plain text parts from the server, decodes them, and concatenates them yielding the returned value.

The library defines plain text parts as parts with a MIME type of text/plain and without a disposition of 'attachment'.

summary.para: Fetches the specified part from the server and writes the (possibly decoded) bytes into the provided stream.
Any decoding required may be done client-side or server-side (if the server supports RFC 3516).
To calculate the number of bytes that have to be fetched, use the method. (This is useful if you are intending to display a progress bar.)
Optionally you may specify an operation specific timeout, cancellation token, progress callback and write size controller in the parameter.
